It might be cool to have service hooks done in JS. Are you thinking it would be a node.js server?

I just a pull request for a working Convore service hook. As stated previously, I'm a newbie to Ruby so please excuse the mess. The hook would get a lot cleaner with a good Ruby wrapper around the API.
@aezellisdead mine is coming, it'll take a bit 'coz I'm not that great either
i look at existing service hooks, and they're all just manipulating json into something else and pushing to a web server.
@aezellisdead yes, node.js.  no ETA though.
it won't be fun for me to port them ALL, but i have some plans for overhauling them that i'm super excited about.  node.js service hooks is the least interesting of those plans :)

I am learning to love.
For non-members you could set a cookie on the single message page (checkbox) remembering the decision to redirect to topic.
@eik3 Yeah, before we add it, we've been debating whether to link to a certain message standalone like Twitter does.
With some extra effort, you could even give the user a setting "always show message deeplink in topic" and redirect the logged in user to the topic.
@eik3 So yeah, it's on our minds, but we have a decision to make about it still :)

What I'm missing in convore is the ability to deep-link a message such as https://convore.com/github/convore-service-hook/88933/ The work-around atm is getting the msg-id from the source, but I guess that's not the most comfortable way for every user ;)
@eik3 Currently it just brings you to the topic and makes sure to highlight the message

The scrolling and stuff all happens in Javascript.  To a crawler or other non-js-enabled clients, the direct link is really no different from the topic link.  I dunno, it just would feel cleaner if there were some way to link to a page with only a single message.  Maybe it wouldn't, we need to experiment around with it IMO.

I see, valid point. From that perspective it might be better to have the message on a single page with a link "see this message in topic". That would be one extra step for the regular user, but e.g. I'm used to that on twitter ("in reply to") to see the message context. As always, compromise UX vs. clean sys. design

the url /group/topic/msgid suggests a single msg page and /group/topic/#msgid would be the in-topic-context url that could be linked from the msg page. ATM the /g/t/msgid url renders the full topic page, which doesn't feel right to me.
I'd clearly prefer the way it currently it - highlight and scroll to that point in the discussion. What are the arguments for the standalone approach?
Yep, all things to consider.  Although in general we're extremely leery of adding settings.
Man why does everything have to be a tradeoff? Haha!
@evilbot the laws
for later reference: convore bookmarklets can be found at https://gist.github.com/824729
Glad that's being considered. Almost the first thing I thought about when I woke this morning was suggesting an easy way to link to a specific comment ^
